title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: Goal: Showcase core functionalities DeepRHealth::medcode module. Supports major medical coding systems (e.g., ICD, ATC) natively R. Built inspiration Python-based PyHealth.medcode. Code Lookup Hierarchy Navigation (Ancestors/Descendants) Cross-System Mapping ATC Specific Utilities

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: Loading Package & Dependencies ’ll load package directly source using devtools::load_all(). requires running presentation package’s root directory. also load necessary packages like knitr.
code: # Load required libraries for loading and display library(devtools) library(knitr) library(rappdirs) # Used by DeepRHealth internally for caching library(fs) # Used by DeepRHealth internally for caching  # Load all functions, data, etc. from the DeepRHealth package source # IMPORTANT: Ensure R's working directory is the package root! load_all(".")  # Optional: Display where medcode data would be cached # cache_dir <- user_cache_dir("DeepRHealth", "medcode") # print(paste("Data cache directory:", cache_dir))  # NOTE: Assume necessary data (e.g., ICD9CM.csv) is pre-cached for demo speed.

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: package automatically downloads required medical code datasets (CSVs) caches locally faster offline use. Uses rappdirs find user-specific cache directory. download_medcode() function checks cache first; downloads file missing. Let’s see data /cached:
code: # Get the platform-specific cache directory path cache_dir <- rappdirs::user_cache_dir("DeepRHealth", "medcode") print(paste("Data cache directory:", cache_dir)) ## [1] "Data cache directory: ~/.cache/DeepRHealth"

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: (step ensures data file exists locally, downloading necessary)
code: # Specify the dataset name (e.g., "ICD9CM") dataset_name <- "ICD9CM"  # Call the function - returns path. Downloads ONLY if not cached. # NOTE: For a live demo, ensure network access OR pre-cache the file! #       We assume it's pre-cached here. file_path <- download_medcode(name = dataset_name)  print(paste("Path for", dataset_name, ":", file_path)) ## [1] "Path for ICD9CM : ~/.cache/RHealth/medcode/ICD9CM.csv" print(paste("File exists:", fs::file_exists(file_path))) ## [1] "File exists: TRUE"

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: load_medcode() function used internally functions (lookup_code, get_ancestors, etc.). first calls download_medcode() ensure data file available locally. , reads CSV file R data frame (tibble) using readr::read_csv. Example: Loading ICD9CM data
code: # Load the data using the function # This implicitly calls download_medcode first icd9_data_example <- load_medcode("ICD9CM")  # Confirm data is loaded by checking dimensions and showing first few rows print(paste("Loaded ICD9CM - Dimensions:", paste(dim(icd9_data_example), collapse = " x "))) ## [1] "Loaded ICD9CM - Dimensions: 17736 x 3" print("First few rows:") ## [1] "First few rows:" kable(head(icd9_data_example))

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: function retrieves description potentially details specific medical code within given coding system. Example: Look ICD-9-CM code “428.0”
code: # Input: code string and system name code_info <- lookup_code(code = "428.0", system = "ICD9CM")  # Output: A tibble/data frame row with information # Using kable() for potentially nicer table output in the presentation kable(code_info)

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: function navigates code hierarchy upwards find parent ancestor codes. Example: Find ancestors ICD-9-CM code “428.22” (Systolic heart failure, acute chronic)
code: # Input: code string and system name ancestors <- get_ancestors(code = "428.22", system = "ICD9CM")  # Output: A character vector of ancestor codes print(ancestors) ##       428.22        428.2          428   420-429.99   390-459.99  ##      "428.2"        "428" "420-429.99" "390-459.99" "001-999.99"

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: function navigates code hierarchy downwards find child descendant codes. Example: Find descendants ICD-9-CM code “428” (Heart failure)
code: # Input: code string and system name descendants <- get_descendants(code = "428", system = "ICD9CM")  # Output: A character vector of descendant codes (can be long!) print(head(descendants)) # Show only the first few for brevity ## [1] "428.4" "428.1" "428.0" "428.3" "428.2" "428.9" print(paste("Total descendants found:", length(descendants))) ## [1] "Total descendants found: 18"

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: let’s see mappings (crosswalks) currently supported: supported_cross() function returns list identifiers available code system mappings within package.
code: # Call the function to get the list of supported crosswalks available_crosswalks <- supported_cross()  # Print the available mapping identifiers print(available_crosswalks) ## [1] "ICD9CM_to_CCSCM"      "ICD9PROC_to_CCSPROC"  "ICD10CM_to_CCSCM"     ## [4] "ICD10PROC_to_CCSPROC" "NDC_to_ATC"

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: function translates codes one coding system another using pre-defined mapping tables. Example: Map ICD-9-CM “428.0” CCSCM system (Clinical Classifications Software)
code: # Input: code, source system (from), target system (to) mapped_code <- map_code(code = "428.0", from = "ICD9CM", to = "CCSCM")  # Output: The corresponding code(s) in the target system print(mapped_code) ## [1] "108"

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: Now let’s look utilities specifically designed ATC (Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical) classification system drugs.

title: DeepRHealth::medcode Module Demo
text: utility function truncates ATC code get representation different classification levels (L1 L5). Example: Convert ATC code “L01BA01” (Methotrexate)
code: atc_code <- "L01BA01"  # Get code representations at different levels print(paste("L1 (Anatomical Main Group):", atc_convert(atc_code, level = 1))) # L ## [1] "L1 (Anatomical Main Group): L" print(paste("L3 (Therapeutic Subgroup):", atc_convert(atc_code, level = 3))) # L01 ## [1] "L3 (Therapeutic Subgroup): L01" print(paste("L4 (Chemical Subgroup):", atc_convert(atc_code, level = 4))) # L01B ## [1] "L4 (Chemical Subgroup): L01B" # Level 5 is usually the full substance code

title: Descriptions
text: dataset module foundation RHealth. converts raw, multi‑table Electronic‑Health‑Record (EHR) dumps tidy, task‑ready tensors every downstream deep‑learning model can consume. can download sample dataset (MIMIC-IV Demo, version 2.2) directly PhysioNet using following link: 👉 https://physionet.org/content/mimic-iv-demo/2.2/#files-panel

title: Descriptions
text: Built‑CSV → Parquet caching via DuckDB (×10 faster reloads). Optional dev mode – keep first N patients lightning‑fast iteration. Parallel sample generation future & progressr.

title: Descriptions
text: Convert dataset model‑ready SampleDataset:
code: data_dir <- "/Users/yourname/datasets/mimiciv/"  ds <- MIMIC4EHRDataset$new(   root = data_dir,   tables = c("patients", "admissions", "diagnoses_icd", "procedures_icd", "prescriptions"),   dataset_name = "mimic4_ehr",   dev = TRUE )  ds$stats() #> Dataset : mimic4_ehr #> Dev mode : TRUE #> Patients : 1 000 #> Events   : 2 187 540 task    <- Readmission30DaysMIMIC4$new() samples <- ds$set_task(task)

title: Descriptions
text: Every dataset described single YAML file. file_path – relative root HTTP(S) URL. patient_id – column containing subject identifier. timestamp – single column list columns (concatenated). attributes – columns expose; automatically renamed table/column. join – optional list auxiliary tables merge one pass. Load & validate R:
code: version: "1.4" tables:   admissions:     file_path: "ADMISSIONS.csv.gz"     patient_id: "subject_id"     timestamp: "admittime"     attributes:       - hadm_id       - admission_type       - discharge_location     join:       - file_path: "ICUSTAYS.csv.gz"         on: hadm_id         how: left         columns: [icustay_id, first_careunit] cfg <- load_yaml_config("configs/mimic4_ehr.yaml") print(cfg)

title: Descriptions
text: Patient behaves like mini‑dataset: can query visits, length‑‑stay, time‑series windows, … without touching patient’s data.
code: BaseDataset            # keeper of *all events*  └── Patient           # one subject’s events (lazy filtered)       └── Event        # lightweight list of {type, timestamp, attributes}

title: Descriptions
text: BaseDataset$set_task() applies user‑defined BaseTask: pre_filter() – drop events patients globally. call(patient) – returns zero, one, many (input, target) pairs. field converted declared Processor torch_tensor. resulting SampleDataset supports: .__getitem__() # single sample .__len__() # length plugs straight torch’s dataloader().

title: Descriptions
text: Use dev = TRUE development keep iteration times 2 s.
code: # Inspect the first 20 events ds$unique_patient_ids()  # Examine one patient pat <- ds$get_patient("123456") print(pat)

title: Descriptions
text: task module sits dataset layer deep‑learning models. task tells RHealth predict, slices data use, turn patient’s raw events (input, target) samples.

title: Descriptions
text: BaseDataset provides lazy access every patient’s events. events matter (pre_filter()). aggregate patient’s timeline one samples (call()). exact input/output schema RHealth can choose right Processor encode data torch tensors. resulting SampleDataset plugs straight torch.

title: Descriptions
code: # Skeleton for your own task ---------------------------------------------- MyCoolTask <- R6::R6Class(   "MyCoolTask",   inherit = BaseTask,   public = list(     initialize = function() {       super$initialize(         task_name     = "MyCoolTask",         input_schema  = list(labs = "timeseries",                              diagnoses = "sequence"),         output_schema = list(outcome = "binary")       )     },      pre_filter = function(df) {       # keep only labs & diagnoses to save RAM       df$select(pl$col(c("labevents/valuenum",                          "diagnoses_icd/icd_code",                          "timestamp",                          "patient_id",                          "event_type")))     },      call = function(patient) {       # ... build samples here ...     }   ) )

title: Descriptions
text: BaseDataset$set_task(task) RHealth: Reads task$input_schema / task$output_schema. Calls get_processor(type) instantiate matching Processor (TimeseriesProcessor, SequenceProcessor, …). sample emitted task$call() encoded fly torch_tensors stored SampleDataset. means never import torch inside task – stick base R objects (numeric, character, matrix, data.frame, lists).

title: Descriptions
code: ds      <- MIMIC4Dataset$new(root = "~/mimic4", tables = ...) mort30  <- InHospitalMortalityMIMIC4$new(input_window_hours = 48) samples <- ds$set_task(mort30, num_workers = 4)

title: Descriptions
text: model module delivers ready‑‑train neural‑network architectures thin BaseModel contract keeps every model compatible rest RHealth.

title: Descriptions
text: Every RHealth model must able : Understand dataset – read input/output schema work dimensions automatically. Pick right loss – binary, multiclass, multilabel, regression. Turn logits probabilities validation metrics. Run CPU CUDA transparently. BaseModel centralises chores concrete models can focus architecture.

title: Descriptions
text: Rule thumb: architecture needs forward method uses single label, can inherit BaseModel forget loss/prob helpers.

title: Descriptions
text: SequenceProcessor → nn_embedding TimeseriesProcessor → nn_linear Pads sequences index 0 safely remaps padding_idx = 1.

previous_headings: RHealth > 3 Model Module > 3.3 Helper building blocks
title: Descriptions
text: drop‑GRU/LSTM/RNN layer : 1‑based index safety (important R!). mask support can mix sequences different length. learnable null_hidden vector empty sequences (avoids NaNs). Bidirectional option automatic hidden‑state merging.

title: Descriptions
text: One RNNLayer per input feature (diagnoses, procedures, labs …). Hidden vectors concatenated → nn_linear → logits. Works ‑‑‑box binary / multi‑class / regression tasks. Instantiation:
code: inputs  ─▶  EmbeddingModel  ─▶  per‑feature RNNLayer  ─┐                                                       ├─▶ concat ─▶ FC ─▶ logits labels   ──────────────────────────────────────────────┘ model <- RNN(   dataset       = samples,     # a SampleDataset from `set_task()`   embedding_dim = 128,   hidden_dim    = 128 )

title: Descriptions
text: Subclass BaseModel (another concrete model). Add layers initialize(), making sure call super$initialize(dataset). Implement forward(inputs). Checklist: Call super$initialize(dataset) Use self$get_output_size() instead hard‑coding dimensions Return named list containing least loss, y_prob
code: MyDense <- torch::nn_module(   "MyDense",   inherit = BaseModel,    initialize = function(dataset, hidden = 256) {     super$initialize(dataset)     in_dim  <- sum(purrr::map_int(dataset$input_processors, "size"))     out_dim <- self$get_output_size()     self$fc1 <- nn_linear(in_dim, hidden)     self$fc2 <- nn_linear(hidden, out_dim)   },    forward = function(inputs) {     # Flatten and concat all features     x <- torch::torch_cat(purrr::flatten(inputs), dim = 2)     logits <- self$fc2(torch_relu(self$fc1(x)))      list(       loss   = self$get_loss_function()(logits, inputs[[self$label_keys]]$to(logits$device)),       y_prob = self$prepare_y_prob(logits)     )   } )

title: Descriptions
text: Trainer module provides batteries‑included training loop RHealth model built torch. mirrors PyHealth’s Python trainer, bringing familiar conveniences R ecosystem: dynamic steps_per_epoch (loop dataloader indefinitely); smart weight‑decay parameter groups (skip bias / LayerNorm); automatic gradient clipping; experiment folders file logging via {futile.logger}; optional CLI progress bars (cli::cli_progress_bar()).

title: Descriptions
text: Logs & checkpoints:
code: library(RHealth)  ## 1.  Build dataset & task ----------------------------------------------- ds      <- MIMIC4Dataset$new(root = "~/mimic4",                              tables = c("patients", "admissions", "labevents"),                              config_path = system.file("configs/mimic4_ehr.yaml", package = "RHealth")) task    <- InHospitalMortalityMIMIC4$new(input_window_hours = 48) samples <- ds$set_task(task)  splits <- split_by_patient(samples, c(0.8, 0.1, 0.1)) train_dl <- get_dataloader(splits[[1]], batch_size = 32, shuffle = TRUE) val_dl <- get_dataloader(splits[[2]], batch_size = 32) test_dl <- get_dataloader(splits[[3]], batch_size = 32)  ## 2.  Build model --------------------------------------------------------- model <- RNN(samples, embedding_dim = 128, hidden_dim = 128)  ## 3.  Kick off training --------------------------------------------------- trainer <- Trainer$new(model,                        metrics      = c("auroc", "auprc"),                        output_path  = "experiments",                        exp_name     = "mortality_rnn")  trainer$train(               train_dataloader = train_dl,               val_dataloader = val_dl,               epochs = 10,               optimizer_params = list(lr = 1e-3),               monitor = "roc_auc") experiments/ └─ mortality_rnn/    ├─ train.log    ├─ last.ckpt      # after every epoch    └─ best.ckpt      # whenever AUROC improves

title: Descriptions
text: RHealth currently active development. initial phase focuses establishing two foundational modules: EHR Database Module: module developed provide standardized framework ingesting, processing, managing diverse Electronic Health Record (EHR) datasets. aims support public datasets like MIMIC-III, MIMIC-IV, eICU, well user-specific data formats OMOP-CDM. goal ensure data consistency subsequent modeling tasks. EHR Code Mapping Module (medcode): module, core medcode component, facilitates mapping within various medical coding systems (e.g., ICD, NDC, RxNorm). Key functionalities like code lookup, hierarchy navigation, cross-system mapping, ATC utilities already implemented, demonstrated examples . Looking ahead, development roadmap includes expansion RHealth several key modules enhancements: Healthcare DL Core Module: module integrate traditional machine learning models (e.g., Random Forests, Support Vector Machines) state---art healthcare-specific deep learning models (e.g., RETAIN, AdaCare, Transformers, graph networks, convolutional networks, recurrent networks). Prediction Task Module: module designed handle various clinical prediction tasks using EHR data, including patient-level predictions (e.g., mortality, disease risk), intra-visit predictions (e.g., length stay, drug recommendation), inter-visit predictions (e.g., readmission risk, future diagnoses). Support Multi-modal Data Integration: Enhancements handle integrate diverse data types beyond structured EHR data. Clinical Trial Applications: Developing functionalities support research analysis context clinical trials. Large Language Model (LLM) Enhancement: Exploring integration LLMs augment package capabilities. RHealth aims provide R community powerful user-friendly toolkit healthcare predictive modeling using deep learning. glad hear feedbacks suggestions via email submitting issues.

title: A Deep Learning Toolkit for Healthcare Predictive Modeling
text: Dataset module foundation RHealth. transforms raw, multi-table Electronic Health Record (EHR) dumps tidy, task-ready tensors downstream model can consume. Key Features: Efficient Ingestion: Streams large CSVs using Polars LazyFrame avoid loading massive files RAM. Data Harmonisation: Merges heterogeneous tables single, canonical event table. Built-Caching: Uses DuckDB CSV → Parquet caching, enabling 10x faster reloads. Dev Mode: Allows lightning-fast iteration using small subset patients. can download sample dataset (MIMIC-IV Demo, version 2.2) directly PhysioNet using following link: 👉 https://physionet.org/content/mimic-iv-demo/2.2/#files-panel Quick Start: Define dataset source files using YAML configuration.
code: # The YAML config defines tables, patient IDs, timestamps, and attributes # See the full documentation for details on the YAML structure.  # Load the dataset data_dir <- "/Users/yourname/datasets/mimiciv/"  ds <- MIMIC4EHRDataset$new(   root = data_dir,   tables = c("patients", "admissions", "diagnoses_icd", "procedures_icd", "prescriptions"),   dataset_name = "mimic4_ehr",   dev = TRUE )  ds$stats() #> Dataset : mimic4_ehr #> Dev mode : TRUE #> Patients : 1 000 #> Events   : 2 187 540

text: Task module defines prediction problem. tells RHealth predict, data use, generate (input, target) samples patient’s event timeline. task defined subclassing BaseTask implementing call() method. Example Task Definition: Generating Samples: task defined, use dataset create SampleDataset compatible torch.
code: MyReadmissionTask <- R6::R6Class(   "MyReadmissionTask",   inherit = BaseTask,   public = list(     initialize = function() {       super$initialize(         task_name     = "MyReadmissionTask",         input_schema  = list(diagnoses = "sequence", procedures = "sequence"),         output_schema = list(outcome = "binary")       )     },     call = function(patient) {       # Your logic to generate samples for a single patient...       # This should return a list or list-of-lists with named fields       # matching the input/output schemas.              # Example:       # list(       #   diagnoses = c("401.9", "250.00"),       #   procedures = c("88.72"),       #   outcome = 1       # )     }   ) ) task    <- Readmission30DaysMIMIC4$new() # A built-in task samples <- ds$set_task(task)

title: A Deep Learning Toolkit for Healthcare Predictive Modeling
text: Model module provides ready--use neural network architectures. models inherit BaseModel, automates dimension calculation, loss function selection, device management (CPU/GPU). Built-Models: RHealth includes reference implementations like RNN, can instantiated one line: Custom Models: can easily write model inheriting BaseModel.
code: model <- RNN(   dataset       = samples, # The SampleDataset from set_task()   embedding_dim = 128,   hidden_dim    = 128 ) MyDenseNet <- torch::nn_module(   "MyDenseNet",   inherit = BaseModel,   initialize = function(dataset, hidden_dim = 256) {     super$initialize(dataset) # IMPORTANT: handles schema setup          # Calculate input/output dimensions automatically     in_dim  <- sum(purrr::map_int(dataset$input_processors, "size"))     out_dim <- self$get_output_size()      self$fc1 <- nn_linear(in_dim, hidden_dim)     self$fc2 <- nn_linear(hidden_dim, out_dim)   },   forward = function(inputs) {     # Flatten and concatenate all input features     x <- torch::torch_cat(purrr::flatten(inputs), dim = 2)     logits <- self$fc2(torch_relu(self$fc1(x)))      # Return loss and probabilities     list(       loss   = self$get_loss_function()(logits, inputs[[self$label_keys]]),       y_prob = self$prepare_y_prob(logits)     )   } )

title: A Deep Learning Toolkit for Healthcare Predictive Modeling
text: Trainer module provides high-level, configurable training loop handles logging, checkpointing, evaluation, progress bars. Example Training Workflow: Logs model checkpoints (best.ckpt, last.ckpt) saved automatically experiments/mortality_rnn/.
code: # 1. Create data loaders splits <- split_by_patient(samples, c(0.8, 0.1, 0.1)) train_dl <- get_dataloader(splits[[1]], batch_size = 32, shuffle = TRUE) val_dl <- get_dataloader(splits[[2]], batch_size = 32) test_dl <- get_dataloader(splits[[3]], batch_size = 32)  # 2. Instantiate a model model <- RNN(train_dl, embedding_dim = 128, hidden_dim = 128)  # 3. Set up the trainer trainer <- Trainer$new(     model,     metrics     = c("auroc", "auprc"),     output_path = "experiments",     exp_name    = "mortality_rnn" )  # 4. Start training trainer$train(   train_dataloader = train_dl,   val_dataloader = val_dl,   epochs = 10,   optimizer_params = list(lr = 1e-3),   monitor = "roc_auc" )

title: A Deep Learning Toolkit for Healthcare Predictive Modeling
text: RHealth active development. roadmap includes: Healthcare DL Core Module: Adding SoTA models like RETAIN, AdaCare, Transformers. Prediction Task Module: Adding built-tasks common clinical predictions (e.g., length stay, readmission risk). Multi-modal Data: Enhancing support integrating imaging, genomics, clinical notes. LLM Integration: Augmenting package capabilities Large Language Models. welcome feedback contributions! Please submit issue GitHub contact maintainers.

title: BaseDataset — R6 infrastructure for clinical event datasets — BaseDataset
text: BaseDataset class mirrors rhealth's BaseDataset, providing fully‑featured, YAML driven loader converts multi‑table electronic health records single event table.  supports: URL local‐file ingestion (automatic .csv / .csv.gz fallback). Per‑table joins declared config. Flexible timestamp parsing (single multi‑column). dev mode caps number patients rapid prototyping. Multi‑threaded sample generation progress bars. ‑stream, cooperates BaseTask (task definition), Patient (per‑subject wrapper), SampleDataset (collection input/output pairs).

title: RNNLayer Class — RNNLayer
text: input_size number expected features input x hidden_size number features hidden state h rnn_type Character, one "GRU", "LSTM", "RNN". Default "GRU". num_layers Number recurrent layers. E.g., setting num_layers=2 mean stacking two GRUs together form stacked GRU, second GRU taking outputs first GRU computing final results. Default: 1 dropout non-zero, introduces Dropout layer outputs GRU layer except last layer, dropout probability equal dropout. Default: 0 bidirectional TRUE, becomes bidirectional GRU. Default: FALSE

title: RNNLayer Class — RNNLayer
text: Key design points Accepts mask indicating valid time steps (1‑based indexing respected). Uses pack_padded_sequence + pad_packed_sequence efficiency. Samples whose sequence length zero (‑zero rows) skipped RNN computation later filled learnable parameter null_hidden downstream layers always receive hidden vector. Works unidirectional bidirectional networks. bidirectional case, last hidden state built forward last step backward first step, projected back hidden_size.

Binary Classification Metrics (Python‐style API) — binary_metrics_fn
text: configurable evaluator binary classification tasks.  function reproduces behaviour Python’s binary_metrics_fn, covering classical discrimination metrics (ROC‑AUC, F1, accuracy, …​) well calibration metrics (ECE / adaptive ECE). Supported metrics names: "pr_auc"  – Precision‑Recall area curve "roc_auc" – Receiver‑Operating‑Characteristic area curve "accuracy", "balanced_accuracy", "f1", "precision", "recall" "cohen_kappa" – Cohen’s κ "jaccard"    – Jaccard index (intersection‑‑union) "ECE"        – Expected Calibration Error (equal‑width bins) "ECE_adapt"  – Adaptive ECE (equal‑size bins)

title: Binary Classification Metrics (Python‐style API) — binary_metrics_fn
text: y_true Numeric vector ground‑truth labels (0 / 1). y_prob Numeric vector predicted probabilities positive class. metrics Character vector listing metrics compute.  Default c("pr_auc","roc_auc","f1"). threshold Numeric decision threshold used convert probabilities hard labels (y_pred).  Default 0.5.

title: Binary Classification Metrics (Python‐style API) — binary_metrics_fn
text: Named numeric vector one element per requested metric.

title: Binary Classification Metrics (Python‐style API) — binary_metrics_fn
code: set.seed(42) y_true <- rbinom(100, 1, 0.4) y_prob <- runif(100) binary_metrics_fn(y_true, y_prob, metrics = c("accuracy", "ECE")) #>  accuracy       ECE  #> 0.5400000 0.3084428
